newsitem.title: FRANCE: McQueen brutalises staid Givenchy staples.
newsitem.headline: McQueen brutalises staid Givenchy staples.

text.p: Angry young British designer Alexander McQueen, enfant terrible of catwalk shock tactics, let rip at the staid house of Givenchy with a hard-core ready-to-wear show on Wednesday.

After his first controversial couture show for the staid label was panned by the French papers in January, McQueen seems to have found a working formula that somehow makes his violent fashion sense compatible with his new job.
McQueen took old man Givenchy's staple ingredients and gave them his own salty modern twist, creating a high-speed, sexually charged spectacle set in a disused horse market.

He did it by fashioning leather -- palomino, emerald or violet -- into sexy bustier dresses punched full of holes, dyeing snakeskin lavender for floor-length coats and tailored jackets and, in an ultimate calculation, even put Kate Moss in a Bettina blouse of sheer black lace.
The result was often vulgar and aggressive, for the hard-hearted street-walker rather than the matronly society hostess.
And while panther print fur minis, fishnet stockings and stiletto-heeled vinyl boots may not be what Givenchy's ladylike clients were hoping for, McQueen didn't forget them.

That's why the show featured plenty of tame grey or pinstriped trouser suits, albeit with pointy power shoulders, close-to-the-body dresses reminiscent of the 1950s that were sensual but in good taste, and a beige evening ensemble of chiffon that swirled delicately about the knees.
"It shows there are two sides of Alexander: superb tailoring and master creation on a women, and the other side is just crazy," said Joan Burstein, owner of Brown's in Britain.
McQueen hits out at his critics in an interview in the current issue of Newsweek magazine, comparing them to Hitler.

"My clothes are out there on a limb and I get slagged for it," he said. "It's like Hitler and the Holocaust. He destroyed millions of people because he didn't understand. That's what a lot of people have done to me because they don't understand what I do."
Many fashion insiders shrugged the statement off as typical McQueen provocation.

"There's a lot of violence in his collections, but a lot of energy too, and I think people are disturbed by it," said Nicole Fischelis of Saks Fifth Avenue. "I like what he does intellectually, but I think he likes to create controversy."

At Chanel, German designer Karl Lagerfeld resuscitated Coco Chanel's dalliance with Russia in Kandinsky motif embroidery on slim black evening wear, a blue coat with red Cossack embroidery and the pale, translucent make-up of flapper girls.
There were oversized wool coats for severe Russian winters and soft, cropped, nubby tweed jackets over wide boyish trousers that the grand old lady might have worn herself.
Then Lagerfeld zoomed decades forward to sexy black or navy suits with the heavy shoulders of power dressing, short pleated skirts and stiletto heels.

"It seemed to be a very eclectic collection. He represented both the soft and sporty clothes and also very strict tailoring in the suits and dresses. There was something for everyone," said Dawn Mello, president of Bergdorf Goodman department store.
Power-dressing is catching on in a big way this season.
Brazilian designer Ocimar Versolato showed it in his hard-edged, square-shouldered zip-up dresses that recall designer Claude Montana, one of the initiators of the genre.
Hemlines, when they were not at the instep, were high on the thigh, especially on a fringed, single-sleeved black cocktail number and a bridal mini of lace petals.

But Versolato's forte is his evening wear, where he put to use his skilled hand at draping. That meant undulating black velvet skirts beneath off-the-shoulder knit bodices, or plum chiffon veiling a bubblegum pink satin brassiere and skirt.
